At the eleventh hour in the middle of a global pandemic, Congress is voting on a 24-hour spending bill and not legislation to help the American people and businesses who are suffering. Dysfunction has become the norm in Washington, and the American people are the ones who suffer.

-- $284 billion for the Paycheck Protection Program, which was set up to support small businesses. 

Performance venues and other cultural institutions would now also be eligible for PPP under this deal. 

https://www.washingtonpost.com

-- $600 survival checks for all documented residents earning up to $75k. Those earning $75-99k will receive less, and those earning over $99k get nothing.  

For families, $600 is allocated per adult and child, so a family of 4 could get up to $2400 - depending on their income.

Here's what we know so far about the COVID relief package:

-- $300/week in federal unemployment for 11 weeks. This is on top of what you already receive from the state.

-- $25 billion in rental assistance. The deal also keeps in place an eviction moratorium for some renters.

Madam Speaker – do the right thing for America. Hear these two bills separately, and don’t ask us to vote until we can read the legislation.

Many members– including me– realize that some form of legislation on both issues is necessary, but they are TWO separate issues. We want to support reasonable COVID relief; and we want a budget debate w/ discussion on long-term debt (hence, my “one subject at a time” bill).
And since COVID relief is more popular than budget approval, she wanted to reserve the option of combining two bills into one – to make it all more appealing.

Budget discussions should be dictated by the calendar, and COVID relief by government-caused constituent need. But Speaker Pelosi feared that acting on the COVID bill before the election could have been favorable to President Trump… so she held off.

On this Sunday evening, there are two major issues on the congressional docket: The ‘21 budget, and COVID relief. With a combined fiscal impact of some $2.3 trillion and about 90 of my democrat colleagues at home, neither issue should be on the agenda at this late date.
